Hi Tim, a request for graphics modification, in your excellent short: The goal, for viewers, is grasping the concept of " endlessly falling around the earth". Means: Start where you did, showing a high object, with a sideways velocity, arcing out a ways by the time it hits the ground. Specific request: Show a discrete-difference series of such arcs, higher and higher initial sideways velocities, with impact points farther and farther out. with the arcs getting closer and closer to the earth's curvature, until... endlessly falling around the earth, in orbit. Intuitively clearer, to a non-Kerbil viewer.

You missed the fact that the necessary horizontal speed greatly depends on your orbit height (the length of your spaceladder).
While the ISS has a horizontal speed of about 7500 m/s at 350 to 400 km height, geostationary satellites move at 3000 m/s at 35.000 km and the Moon for example is moving with 1000 m/s on its orbit.

technical flaw of the graphic at 0:23 "its lowest point, or perigee is barely beyond the Earth's centre". Correct, but the path is an ellipse CENTERED at the center of the Earth, not an ellipse with the vertex at the center of the Earth. 0:53 to 0:58 as the rocket accelerates, and the orbit expands, this is shown incorrectly in the same way as the ball example at 0:23. If the Ball was made of Dark Matter to avoid the small issue of hitting and being stopped by the Earth, however still be influenced by gravity, we can add validity to the thought experiment (assuming dark matter would clump!) Main point, the orbit is ALWAYS centered at the combined center of mass of the two objects, and without friction (or electro-weak force) the orbit will achieve the same altitude on the opposite side of the planet no matter if it passes thru the planet or stays above the atmosphere. Same thing as having a hole all they way thru the Earth and dropping a ball (zero horizontal component of velocity). the ball falls faster and faster until it flys past the center of the Earth and keeps on going to the opposite side, terminating at the same altitude, whereby you buddy catches the ball at zero vertical velocity before it falls again.

This definition is satisfactory for most cases. Difference between the case of a suborbital rocket like New Shepherd and SN20 on its orbital flight is that the latter will certainly fly in an orbital trajectory, but it is interrupted by the atmosphere, not the surface of Earth on its own. Relatively speaking, if a starship aerobrakes on Mars, then it’d be in a orbital and then suborbital trajectory instead of a hyperbolic trajectory as it would be to start and if it weren’t interrupted by the Martian atmosphere.

My point: the atmosphere of a planet is mutually exclusive from the instantaneous status of the objects that orbit it. Newton’s first law: An object tends to stay in motion unless or until perturbed.

Good content but you rushed through it a bit too quickly. Slow it down 20% and it will be more comprehensible.

Quick (and potentially dumb) question though - why do the conditions of the Kessler Syndrome (space junk problem) really exist? I'm sure I am thinking about this the wrong way, but it seems like space junk would need to be orbiting at the exact speed needed to maintain orbit (~7,500 m/s) for it to become a long-term problem. Slower, and it will de-orbit and burn up in the atmosphere. Faster, and it will escape Earth's orbit and veer off into space(-ish). Surely all space junk cannot be orbiting at exactly ~7,500 m/s? In fact it should be a very small amount that coincidentally hits that exact speed. Is it just that even if it orbits considerably slower or faster it would still take a very long time to de-orbit or escape?

Pretty sure this graphic is entirely wrong. Imagine: There is a shaft going through the center of the planet. You drop a tennis ball into it. What happens? Well the ball doesn’t stop at the center, or near to it. It travels through the shaft to the opposite side of the surface, then back down. It will oscilate (orbit) around the center of the planet.

So no, pretty sure the perigee won’t be close to the center.

(I know the graphic says it’s not to scale, but this is pretty misleading)
